div.p: Greetings. I have nothing at all to report at the moment (reverend father in Christ). Your belongings have been returned to me in good faith; I give the greatest thanks I can.
If this English disaster is true, it will not cease to be of great importance.

I am amazed that our people have been acting so lazily in all matters for a long time now; I hope the force of war does not turn back on the Christians! I will take care of what you have commanded, and I hope Mr. Martinengo will not fail in his duty.
I have read extensively the proceedings of Baden and the affairs of Bern and Savoy, along with the double instructions of the envoys to the people of Bern.
We help mediate for so long until we find ourselves in the middle of it.
The people of Bern are praised by our people for not wanting to abandon the people of Geneva; may they persist and not, as is their custom, recoil from a good beginning.
I have nothing at all, except to let you know that a strong assembly has recently taken place here in Chur.
This has been described due to the following reason: The people of Engadin have had much tension and conflict with the imperial forces for a long time now; it stems from the war on the Adige.
Many times now, the government has been petitioned to quell the defiance and willfulness of their people, to prevent greater unrest.
The government gives smooth words, claiming that these things happened without their knowledge, etc.
Recently, some imperial forces have attacked and plundered an entire village with armed force, capturing some and taking them away with them.
Meanwhile, the people have been active here and there in the mountains and the Alps.
However, when they were warned of this, about 200 Engadiners gathered together and brought their people back home from the emperor's land with armed force.
In response, the imperial forces have mobilized up to 6000 men and positioned them at the borders; however, as we have since learned, they are supposed to have been called back by the government.
Thus, it was very close to the matter escalating into a serious civil war.
Our people have written earnestly to the government; for it seems to our people that the matter is serious and that much is being played out on one thing or another.
The provost of this college, from the Salicetum family, is suffering fatally from a spitting of blood and a rupture of the vein.
From this very illness, two of his sisters passed away last month.
Our bishop is bathing in Fideris.
He affirms that he has read my little book on Providence (for I had given it to him as a gift) diligently and indeed at regular hours.
I was surprised that he was not offended by those things I brought against the papists and Roman frauds.
In the meantime, he has invited me quite humbly to visit him through his people; but I do not go; for he calls me to banquets, etc.
Since I had nothing external to report, I wanted to note these domestic matters, so that I would not write nothing.
Farewell, reverend father in Christ, with all your people, for as long and as happily as possible.
Our people send their regards to you respectfully.
Chur, August 16, 1563.
Your Fabricius.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant overseer of the Church of Zurich, his lord and reverend father in Christ.
Zurich.
